segments.text: So when you're told that over and over and over and over again, how much people disapprove of what you're doing, after a while, you really don't care to do that anymore.
So for a lot of guys, it was a mental trip.
They didn't want to be there anymore.
Okay.
Tell me about what it was like when you came home.
How did people react when you told them you fought in Vietnam?
I was real, you know,
I always got such a sense of pride when my dad said, I fought in World War II, you know, and I fought in Korea.
I, well, I just, you know, I just, you know, swell up inside with pride for what he had done.
And even today you tell people, well, you know, I fought in Vietnam and it's, it's like,
big deal.
Who cares?
Oh, you were over there in all that mess?
Well, to me it wasn't a mess.
A fear that I have is, I have a real fear of communism.
I have never lived in a communistic society
But I've seen the results of communism.
I've been to North Vietnam, and I would not want my kids to grow up like that.
Always fear and fear.
I think we lost the war because of an attitude.
If we wanted to have
If we wanted to have won, we would have, regardless of the cost.
I would have almost did and would have died in Vietnam if I knew that it would have helped to stamp out something that I don't believe in.
I guess the American public has lost its beliefs.
Tell me some more about when you came home, reactions of people.
You were telling me about Veterans Day here at A&M.
Well, my dad, he said that he used to...
that everybody used to wear their uniform on Veterans Day and on Memorial Day.
And it used to be a real time to remember what people fought for.
And I wore my uniform last Memorial Day.
And I didn't see anybody else.
There was no sense of anybody else being proud of.
I know a lot of Vietnam vets.
There's no sense of pride in what they've done.
That time I went to Washington, DC, there was a guy sitting in a wheelchair.
He'd lost both of his legs in Vietnam.
And this little girl, I bet you she wasn't over 16 years old, she walked over with a pole.
She had a long pole with a rope hanging down.
And there was a baby, a doll, hanging on the end of that pole.
And they had taken a match or whatever and scorched that doll all up.
And she threw that thing in his lap.
and said, remember this?
She has absolutely no idea.
The guy goes over there and loses both of his legs so that she can go out in the streets and demonstrate.
And there was no appreciation at all.
And that is the most aggravating thing.
When I, the deal about Texas A&M, I walked into a literature class and a guy, I never killed a baby when I was in Vietnam.
How this thing about baby killers came about, I don't know.
Kids were killed in World War II.
Do we go around calling the World War II vets baby killers?
And there were orphanages bombed and things like that in World War II.
Accidents happen, but that's the cost of war.

And when you got a guy, a freshman in college, walking up to me and calling me a baby killer, it makes me want to go into a, I would just like to bash his face in, because he doesn't know what he's talking about.
I never killed a baby.
in Vietnam.
I killed a whole bunch of people that were trying to kill me.
But I never killed a baby.
So they've locked us into a group and said, all of you guys are like this.
It's frustrating.
You get this sense of you want to scream and tell people
Based on what you experienced, what do you think of our involvement in Southeast Asia?
Do you think it was right or wrong?
What are your feelings on it?
Well, I think any time a government reaches out, we have always been there for people that have asked for our help.
If we stop,

If we had stopped in Vietnam, if we had told the Vietnamese people, oh, I'm really sorry, we just can't get involved, you're just going to have to sell this yourself, then we have lost every idea that this country was based on.
I'm a patriot, I guess, from the soles of my feet up.

If we start and say, oh, no, just like what we had done just now, we have decided, our government has decided, or we have some people in the House that have decided that we're not going to continue democracy in the world.
They just showed us that by not giving aid
in Central America, militarily or financially, whatever.
When we stop spreading democracy, communism comes in.
We gave up and we quit because of pressures of a few people in Vietnam.
And what happened?
Now the whole country is communist.
If we give up,
and allow communism to spread.
It's just like a cancer.
It's going to spread pretty soon.
We're not going to be able to hold it back of our own back doors.
And it's going to come in.
If we let it spread in Central America, it's going to spread just like it has done in Asia, just like it's done in Vietnam.
We stopped it in Korea.
It's a stalemate in Korea.
And if we let it, I think our involvement was justified, to answer your question.
Because we didn't finish our job, I think that hurts.
But it's like all those guys that died, those 55,000 guys, and some of them were good friends of mine, died for nothing because we did not finish what we set out to do.
How have your views changed since the end of the war, or have they?
They're the same.
I'm still a patriot.
I still believe in democracy.
If my government said tomorrow, Bob, we need you to go to Central America to fight against communist aggression, my bags would be packed and I'd be ready to go.
Did you ever question why you were in Vietnam?
One time.
When was that?
after I had been shot.
But I think anybody would question.
But once they patched me up and I was okay,
I think if you're at the steps of death, you're always going to question no matter where you are.
If you're speeding down the road and you hit a telephone pole and you're laying there and you're dying, you're going to question, well, why was I speeding?
I question, what am I doing here?
But as soon as I got okay, I knew why I was there.
And I was helping people that asked for help, because they don't want to live under communist rule.
That's why I was there.
And I questioned the one time, but after that I didn't ever again.
And I still don't to this day.
I still believe.
I put it off.
I put off the takeover.
as long and as well as I could.
I did what I could do, and I'm satisfied with that.
Okay, well, thank you for your time.
Okay.
In general, can you tell me about how the American soldiers felt about the Vietnamese all through the war and up until the time of the pullout?
Not only was there a job to do, but there was also a caring.
It's just like anywhere.
You see somebody in trouble, and people care about people.
So many times, you see GIs just taking kids out of a fire area, risking their lives to help the Vietnamese people.
Even in the pullout, the Army could have just left, but they tried to get as many people as they could out of South Vietnam.
I mean, just as many people as they could get out, they got out.
The dumping of helicopters over the side, personal effects were thrown overboard.
just so they could cram one more person on board ship to bring them to freedom and democracy.
So there was a real caring, a sense of caring between the military and the Vietnamese people.
I think that's, if the people that were demonstrating in the days of the Vietnamese War, if they could have seen, if they would have taken the time to look through
on their political minds, they could have seen that the GI and the South Vietnamese people had relationships.
They had a caring, they cared about each other.
And if they would have looked at that, maybe it would have softened a lot of hearts
the attitudes would have changed.
Why do you think Saigon fell?
Well, because we pulled out.
Why has Lebanon fallen?
Because Israel was pulling out.
Eventually, the Muslims are going to be in complete control of what's going on there
Same thing in Vietnam.
We pulled out what was left to defend.
And a lot of people, a lot of people have died since we pulled out just because they were friends to us.
And why did we pull out?
Because of pressure on...
That's what I said earlier, because of pressure of the...
In my opinion, the private sector needs to keep their nose out of the military business.
Of course we've got our guys going over there to fight, but that's what they're in the military for.
People know what they're doing when they join the military.
It's not just to get a paycheck.
It's to defend them.
You might end up dying.
That's the whole idea of having a military.
The private sector, our Congress, even all the way up to the president, need to leave the military to military business.
If the military was able to stay in Vietnam, who knows what would it be like today?
Or if we had had enough
What I want to say is if we had had enough dedication in what we were doing as the communists had in what they were doing, we would have won that war.
The communists, they had that idea set into their minds.
And no matter what was going to happen, they were going to fight for what they believed in.
We stopped believing in what we were fighting for.

A lot of Vietnam vets are protesting now about why they were there and asking for aid because a lot of them are having mental problems now and many have cancer and stuff and are saying that's caused from Agent Orange that was used to defoliate the jungles.
How do you feel about all that?
Does that show some sort of a...
I think these guys need to...
The Vietnam vet that was wounded in serving his country, I believe, has a legitimate claim.
But a lot of the guys
Like the dope thing in Vietnam.
The dope problem in Vietnam was a choice that you could make.
If you made that choice to get all strung out on dope, then that was your business.
That's a choice that you made.
Now, our government should not have to pay for that.
Now, the Agent Orange thing, I'm not a chemist, so I don't know what effects Agent Orange had on
on our guys.
That one, I think a lot of guys are probably looking for a free ride.
I was probably eligible for a disability.
I would not accept it.
What for?
Just to, you know, I'm able to get out there and make a living.
I was in North Vietnam for 18 months.
A lot of these guys sat back in a foxhole, stuck their gun up out of the foxhole without even ever looking out of it and just pulled the trigger.
And now they want federal aid from the federal government?
Well, that's a bunch of baloney.
They need to start standing up like a man again and go to work and make a living instead of trying to take a free ride from our government.
That's not fair.
that you are proud of what you did and the time that you spent and are proud of the job that you did?
Yeah.
Yeah, I am.
When I say I'm a Vietnam vet, I don't hang my head down when I say it.
And that's, you know, a lot of guys do now because of the way they've been treated.
I thought I fought for what I thought was right, and nobody can take that away from me.
If somebody wants to make an outlandish statement, the way I look at it is they don't know what they're talking about.
If you were to have a message to the college students of today to try to justify or clear up the misconceptions you feel like they have, what would that message be?
Don't judge everything by what you hear.
I think they would really have had to have been there to make a judgment.
Anything else?
What would you tell them as far as if they were needed to defend the country, what would your?
your message to them be as far as whether they should or shouldn't?

Well, my attitude is probably a little different, but I would say if your country, you know, this country gives you everything that you've got, you know, and if we don't, if each individual doesn't really weigh it and say, I'm not willing to give up,
the way of life that I have, my liberty and my democratic society, my pursuit of happiness or whatever.

If they're not willing to make a stand and fight for their freedoms, like the guys that went to Canada during the Vietnam War, I do not think that they should have ever been given a right to come back here.
You know, because they want to turn tail.
And of course, they don't mind receiving all the things that this country has to offer.
But when the country turns around and says, well, you know, we need your help now, if you want to turn tail and run, as far as I'm concerned, you might as well just keep on running and go on.
You know, it's like the people that want a socialistic government.
If you want a socialistic government, go live in Russia.
You know, there's plenty of them around.
Take your pick.
But don't try to push that off on, you know, on my way of life.
I don't want to live in a social government.
I like doing what I do.
If I make it in life, well then that's, I can say, hip hip hooray.
If I don't, well then that's my problem too.
If I'm able to make a million dollars a year, well, I don't want to have to take half of it and give it to somebody else, just because they don't have the willingness to go out there and do it.
I kind of have a thing against college students, just like we were sent into a group.
a lot of that has gone now because I understand now that everything has changed.
The college student attitude is not the same as it was when we were in the war in Vietnam.
We have to fight for what we believe in.
And if we lose the belief in
in the liberties that we have, we might as well give up.
Okay, well thank you again.
Okay.
After the interview we were talking just a second ago and you were telling me about
the marijuana use and I told you about the statistics I heard about VD and marijuana use.
I wanted you to tell me, repeat what you'd said about how the North Vietnamese protected them or helped their cause with the knowing what the American men were going to do over there.
Well, the American males, the sex drive is pretty strong.
So the communists used to infiltrate the South Vietnamese camps.
It was real hard to know who was a communist and who wasn't.
But they would send women in.
that were posing as hookers.
And if I can get blunt with you.
And they would insert razor blades into the private areas.
And when the GI would penetrate, you've got to understand that their idea a lot of times was not to kill the guy.
Their whole idea was if we could do enough damage to where men, GIs couldn't go home and have any kids or demoralize them, that added a lot to their cause.
So when a GI would go to bed with these Viet Cong, not knowing that they were Viet Cong, the razor blades would just
cut them up real bad and do a lot of damage.
So that was one way.
Or some other times the women would go in with grenades.
And G.I.
would be laying there with them and they'd just pull the pins on the grenades and blow them both up.
Just sacrificial.
Did that happen a lot?
After a few times, they really started beefing up security and checking a lot of the civilians that were coming through.
Just stop them at random and check them.
The dope scene, it wasn't just marijuana.
It was just about anything you could get.
Opium was real big.
So easy to get.
Yeah.
Did you see a lot of use?
No, we were not in a position to be really with a lot of our own military.
With our own four guys, if we had ever caught anybody in our group even smoking a marijuana cigarette, we'd have shot them on the spot.
I would have anyway because my life is not worth a marijuana cigarette, some guy getting high.
But most of our guys were, or I never saw anybody in our group
Was there any lacing of marijuana by the North Vietnamese to try to get to the Americans?
They tried to tamper with it?
It's hard to say because you never knew where the supply was coming from.
Did it happen, though?
I'm sure it did.
Also, we were talking about your reconditioning when you came home.
I thought that was interesting.
Tell me a little bit more about that.
Well, you have to understand that when you're in an area and your job is to basically kill, kill, kill, then the military acted real responsible, as far as I was concerned, to get you back into a...
the mode of civilian life.
When we came home, they spent four months setting us up in an apartment.
Instead of waking up in the morning and reaching for your gun or weapon, whatever you used,

they would wake you up and immediately take you and get the newspaper and take you into the kitchen and you'd make coffee and go to the bathroom and brush your teeth and you know whatever they could do to get you back used to living a civilian life instead of a military life and I really shouldn't say military life combat
Combat line, yeah, to get you out of that train of thought.
So they did a good job.
Do you ever have any flashbacks or ever feel like you're seeing Vietnam while you're here?
Yeah, if I see a movie, a lot of times I'll, you know, it'll immediately take me back.
On my way over here, I heard a lot of times it's sound or it's smell or it's something looks familiar.
Mainly, I guess, sound does it.
On my way over here this afternoon, I was walking across the parking lot, and I heard a helicopter.
And out where I live, it's just a lot of brush and trees and jungle and vines and everything.
And when I heard this helicopter, I immediately just took a quick flash and went back to Vietnam.
But I think that's just part of what you can go through.
Just remembering.
It has no negative effects on you though?
No.
It's just like the first time you rode a bicycle.
Sometimes something will happen or if you ever fell down and scraped your hand or knee or whatever, something flashes and it brings you back to the memory of that.
I spend a lot of time there and not always in real good company, so it has a tendency to bring it back.
All right, well, thanks again.
Okay.
